metadata.case_name: Bhaurao Shankar Lokhande & Anr. v. State of Maharashtra

facts.text: Bhaurao Shankar Lokhande, appellant No. 1, was married to the complainant Indubai in about 1956.
Appellant No. 1 married Kamlabai in February 1962, during the lifetime of Indubai.
Deorao Shankar Lokhande, appellant No. 2, is the brother of appellant No. 1.
Appellants No. 1 and 2, together with Kamlabai, her father (accused No. 4) and accused No. 5 (a barber), were tried for offence under S. 494 I.P.C.
Kamlabai, her father and accused No. 5 were acquitted by the Magistrate.
Appellant No. 1 convicted under S. 494 I.P.C. and appellant No. 2 under S. 494 read with S. 114 I.P.C.
Revision to Bombay High Court in Criminal Revision Application No. 388 of 1963 dismissed on August 19, 1963.
Appeal by special leave to Supreme Court.

At the alleged second marriage: Wooden sheets brought, carpet spread, accused No. 1 sat on one sheet, accused No. 3 (Kamlabai) on another nearby. Accused No. 4 performed Puja with Tambya-pitcher, betel leaves and coconut. Two garlands exchanged between accused No. 1 and 3. They struck each other's forehead.
No invocation before sacred fire or saptapadi performed.
No Brahmin priest called, no Mangala Ashtakas chanted, no custom to blow pipe Sher.
Marriage performed at 10 p.m., not at maternal uncle's house (Surpan village) as per custom not requiring it for Gandharva.
Witness Sitaram (PW2): Custom does not require Brahmin priest or barber; father makes boy and girl touch foreheads to complete Gandharva.
Witness Bhagwan (PW3): No necessity for Brahmin priest or Mangala Ashtakas in their community for Gandharva.
Witness Jeebhau (PW4): Witnessed two prior Gandharvas; for last 5-7 years, no Brahmin, barber, Thakur required; formerly essential; maternal uncle or other makes foreheads touch.

legal_issues.text: Whether the alleged second marriage of appellant No. 1 with Kamlabai in 1962 was duly performed in accordance with the religious rites applicable, i.e., essential ceremonies for a valid marriage.
Whether for commission of offence under S. 494 I.P.C., the second marriage must be a valid/solemnized one, or any form of marriage during lifetime of first spouse suffices, even if void.
Whether the marriage was in Gandharva form as per custom in the community, modifying essential ceremonies.

petitioner_arguments.text: Essential ceremonies for a valid marriage were not performed during the proceedings when appellant No. 1 and Kamlabai married each other.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Hindu law essential ceremonies: invocation before sacred fire and saptapadi

respondent_arguments.text: Proceedings of the marriage were in accordance with custom prevalent in the community for Gandharva form of marriage, making it valid.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Custom in community for Gandharva marriage; Mulla's Hindu Law

respondent_arguments.text: Not necessary for offence under S. 494 I.P.C. that second marriage be valid; any form of marriage during lifetime of first wife commits offence even if void.

court_reasoning.text: S. 494 I.P.C. requires 'marries' to mean valid marriage; if not valid, no marriage in eye of law, so not void by reason of first spouse living.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prima facie, whoever marries must mean whoever marries validly.

court_reasoning.text: Under Hindu law pre-1955, second marriage not void; post-HMA S.17, void only if solemnized after commencement and spouse living.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Solemnize means celebrate with proper ceremonies and due form.

court_reasoning.text: Essential ceremonies: invocation before sacred fire and saptapadi; not performed; no evidence custom abrogated them.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Prosecution failed to prove custom continuously observed obtaining force of law.

court_reasoning.text: Ceremonies performed (garlands, puja, forehead touching) insufficient without evidence they alone suffice per custom.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Witness statements do not establish custom dispensing with essentials.

court_reasoning.text: Recent departure (5-7 years) not custom under S.3(a) HMA.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Custom must be continuously and uniformly observed for long time.

holdings.text: Marriage not performed in accordance with customary rites u/s 7 HMA or essential requirements; not solemnized u/s 17 HMA; does not attract S.494 IPC.
For S.494 IPC post-HMA, second marriage must be solemnized to be void u/s 17.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines offence of marrying again during lifetime of spouse; applies if marriage void u/s 17 HMA

statutes_cited.name: Hindu Marriage Act, 1955
statutes_cited.relevance: S.5 conditions for marriage; S.17 voids second marriage if solemnized with spouse living; S.7 requires customary rites; S.3 defines custom

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; convictions of appellant No. 1 under S.494 IPC and appellant No. 2 under S.494 r/w S.114 IPC set aside; appellants acquitted. Bail bonds of appellant No. 1 discharged.

key_quotes.text: 'Solemnize' means, in connection with a marriage, to celebrate the marriage with proper ceremonies and in due form.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines key term for applicability of S.17 HMA and S.494 IPC

key_quotes.text: There are two ceremonies essential to the validity of a marriage... 1 invocation before the sacred fire, and 2 saptapadi.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The expressions 'custom' and 'usage' signify any rule which, having been continuously and uniformly observed for a long time, has obtained the force of law.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why prosecution failed to prove custom
